articles.title: NOVEMBER 1988
articles.summary: The "NOVEMBER 1988" document outlines a packed schedule of events for the San Jose Astronomical Association, encompassing November and December 1988. Key activities include a Mars Watch, a lecture on Lick Observatory's glass maker Charles Feil, multiple star parties, and a discussion/observation of a grazing occultation of Regulus. Other notable events are board meetings, a break for Thanksgiving, and a talk by Dick Hoagland on the "Face on Mars."

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW
articles.summary: The article announces an upcoming General Meeting featuring Lick Observatory Historian Shilo Unruh, who will speak about glassmaker Charles Feil. It also addresses potential issues with missing September Sky & Telescope magazine issues and provides detailed instructions for renewing Astronomy and Telescope Making magazine subscriptions through the SJAA group rate.

articles.title: MARS WATCH - '88
articles.summary: The MarsWatch '88 public star parties were highly successful, attracting approximately 300 attendees on every clear evening. These events significantly increased public awareness of amateur astronomy, the San Jose astronomy club, and clarified common misconceptions about Mars's color. The success is attributed to the many volunteers who dedicated their evenings to the initiative.

articles.title: MEMBERSHIP CARD CONTEST
articles.summary: The SJAA is holding a contest to design a new membership card. Entries are currently being accepted, and if a new design is judged superior to the existing one, the winner will receive a free year's membership to the SJAA.

articles.title: THE SEARCH FOR LIFE ELSEWHERE
articles.summary: Astronomer Andrew Fraknoi will host a full-day program titled 'The Search for Life Elsewhere' at the UC Berkeley campus on Saturday, November 12. This event, cosponsored by UC Berkeley Extension and the Astronomical Society of the Pacific, will cover topics including Mars exploration, exoplanet discoveries, interstellar travel, and the search for extraterrestrial signals. The program is designed for all audiences, requiring no prior science or math background.

articles.title: WHAT'S HAPPIN'N ON HAMILTON
articles.summary: Lick Observatory is currently undergoing significant renovations, including structural upgrades and new elevator installation, expected to continue until early 1989. Due to construction and insurance regulations, public access to the main building area is now restricted by a new gate. This unexpected barrier provides amusement for observatory staff watching unsuspecting visitors, particularly bicyclists and drivers, react with surprise and near-crashes.

articles.title: Night Lectures
articles.summary: This article details the ongoing restoration of an observatory's Main Building, focusing on the structural reinforcement of exterior walls using the shotcrete process and the identification of original fireplaces. Special planning is underway to address earthquake damage to the brick chamber of the 36-inch refractor. Additionally, the 36-inch lens has been expertly repolished by Lick Observatory opticians to correct "crazing," preparing the historic facility for another century of astronomical research.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: This document, titled "ASTRO ADS," presents a collection of classified advertisements from November 1988. It features individuals seeking specific back issues of "Telescope Making" magazine and numerous 'for sale' listings for used astronomical equipment. The equipment offered includes various telescopes (refractors, Schmidt-Cassegrains, Schmidt-Newtonians), mounts, eyepieces, drive correctors, and accessories for general observing and astrophotography, all with contact details and pricing.

articles.title: Equipment for Sale
articles.summary: This document lists various used astronomical equipment for sale by individual sellers, including telescopes from Bausch & Lomb, Celestron, and Meade, as well as a wide range of accessories like eyepieces, finders, motofocus, astrophotography gear, and astronomy handbooks. Each listing provides a description, price (or best offer), and contact information for the seller. All listings are dated October or September 1988.

articles.title: GRAZING OCCULTATION EXPEDITION BY JIM VAN NULAND
articles.summary: This document outlines an upcoming grazing occultation expedition of Regulus on November 30, led by Jim Van Nuland, targeting a site south of Patterson in California's Central Valley. It provides detailed logistical information including directions, contact numbers for site and weather updates, recommended equipment, precise timing for observation, and step-by-step instructions for recording the event. The expedition emphasizes careful preparation and real-time audio recording of stellar disappearances and reappearances.

articles.title: BY: JIM VAN NULAND
articles.summary: This article details recent observations of Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS), describing its appearance as orange or salmon-pink, nestled in an asymmetrical South Equatorial Belt hollow, with a slight dark southern border. It provides practical observing tips, recommending 200-300x magnification and good seeing conditions to locate the GRS within its hollow. The document also includes a corrected table of predicted times (in PST) when the GRS will be centrally visible on Jupiter's disk for observers from November 20xx to December 20xx.

articles.title: BY: BOB FINGERHUT
articles.summary: The Space Shuttle Discovery successfully completed a mission, deploying a TDRS satellite into geosynchronous orbit. This new satellite, combined with an earlier launch, expands U.S. space-based data relay capacity to 85% of the globe, significantly enhancing data return for future shuttle, spacelab, and scientific satellite missions. One more TDRS launch is required before the Hubble Space Telescope can be deployed.

articles.title: DOUBLE, TRIPLE, AND MULTIPLE STARS BY PATRICK DONNELLY
articles.summary: The provided text details the successful STS-26 mission of the Space Shuttle Discovery, including its activities such as photographing Earth targets for environmental monitoring (hurricane damage, floods, drought) and conducting 11 secondary payload experiments, including protein crystal growth. Discovery landed successfully at Edwards AFB and was in excellent condition, with the next mission, STS-27, scheduled for late November or early December.

articles.title: NOAA-11 METEOROLOGICAL SATELLITE LAUNCHED
articles.summary: The NOAA-11 meteorological satellite has been successfully launched into a near-polar orbit at 470 nautical miles. It is equipped with advanced instruments for microwave sounding, ozone monitoring, and search-and-rescue assistance, as well as microprocessors. NOAA-11 will work alongside NOAA-10 to collect vital meteorological data for global weather forecasting, storm tracking, and sea ice monitoring.

articles.title: ISRAEL LAUNCHED ITS FIRST SATELLITE SEPT. 19
articles.summary: Israel successfully launched its first satellite, Offeg-1, on September 19 using a Shavit booster, placing it into a 155 x 717 mile orbit. This event followed a series of other international space launches in early September, including successful communication satellite launches by Japan and Europe, and a weather satellite launch by China. However, one of the European-launched satellites, Gstar-3, experienced a malfunction during its apogee kick-motor firing.

articles.title: LANDSAT OPERATION CUT BACK
articles.summary: Landsat satellite image acquisition will be severely curtailed starting November 1 due to a significant funding shortfall for operating Landsats 4 and 5 in Fiscal Year 1989. Congress appropriated only $9 million, far short of the estimated $26 million required, leading to reduced operations.

articles.title: DOUBLE, TRIPLE, AND MULTIPLE STARS BY PATRICK DONNELLY
articles.summary: This article provides a guided tour of double, triple, and multiple stars within the constellation Cygnus, the Swan. It details specific observing targets like Albireo, Delta Cygni, and 61 Cygni, offering information on their magnitudes, separations, colors, and required equipment for observation. The guide also touches upon the scientific and historical significance of several of these fascinating celestial objects.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: The article provides updates on several comets: Comet Temple Z is dimming as it moves away from Earth and the Sun, while Comet Machholz significantly dimmed after rounding the sun and is unlikely to return due to its parabolic orbit. A new comet, SMM 3 (1988l), was discovered by the Solar Maximum Mission Satellite, observed at magnitude -1, and is believed to be a member of the Kreutz Sungrazing group.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Tempel 2 (1987g)
articles.summary: This document provides an ephemeris for Periodic Comet Tempel 2 (1987g) for late October through early December, detailing its Right Ascension, Declination, Elongation, and visual magnitude. It notes the comet's north and eastward motion, consistent setting time, increasing distance from Earth and Sun, and its proximity to globular cluster M30 around November 24.

articles.title: SEEKING COMETS
articles.summary: Carolyn and Eugene Shoemaker of the U.S. Geological Survey conduct a professional search for comets and asteroids using the 18" Schmidt camera at Mt. Palomar, covering a significant portion of the sky. Through their dedicated survey, they have discovered or co-discovered 14 comets, many of which are faint and have large perihelion distances, making them difficult for amateur astronomers to detect with current equipment.

articles.title: BY: DENISE HUTSON
articles.summary: The author recounts her experiences at the "Mars Watch '88" public star parties, initially attending without her telescope to introduce a friend to astronomy and observe the event. She later brought her own scope, despite initial setup challenges, and discovered immense joy in sharing views of Mars and other celestial objects with an eager public. The article highlights the rewards of astronomy outreach, the camaraderie among amateur astronomers, and the excitement generated by major celestial events.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The SJAA hosts monthly General Meetings at the Red Cross building in Los Gatos, California, featuring guest speakers on various astronomical topics and "Indoor Star Parties" for members to share interests. These meetings, held on the 1st Saturday of each month at 8 PM, foster a friendly atmosphere for enthusiasts of astrophotography, deep sky observation, telescope making, and more. Detailed directions to the venue are also provided.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: Indoor Star Parties are informal Saturday evening gatherings for amateur astronomers to socialize, share equipment, and discuss their common interest in astronomy. These events often include outdoor telescope viewing, astrophotography slideshows, and introductory workshops, with SJAA board meetings also taking place concurrently.

articles.title: FIELD EXPEDITIONS
articles.summary: The SJAA organizes "Star Parties" for astronomical observation on Saturdays near the New Moon. These events vary in location, from sites close to San Jose to destinations like Yosemite National Park, and participants should consult the EPHEMERIS for specific locations.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK
articles.summary: Fremont Peak State Park is a popular observing site for Bay Area amateur astronomers, located 70 miles south of San Jose. It is frequently used for serious deep sky observing and astrophotography during New Moon weekends, often hosting 50-100 telescopes, especially in summer. The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) regularly gathers at Coulter Camp within the park, and the article provides detailed directions to this key astronomical hub.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), detailing different membership types, their associated costs (e.g., membership only, membership with Sky & Telescope, junior), and options for new or renewal applications. It provides instructions on how to submit the application, including payment information and contact details for the treasurer.
